Netflix has unveiled a new Series of Unfortunate Events trailer, showing off Neil Patrick Harris’ excellent portrayal of the evil, wacky, will-stop-at-nothing-to-get-that-money Count Olaf. 
Neil Patrick Harris’ ability to convincingly become any person — whether male or female, young or old, ugly or beautiful — becomes abundantly clear in the latest ASOUE trailer. While some of us may’ve been a little skeptical of his casting initially, it’s hard to imagine anyone else in the role after seeing previews like this. 
The trailer begins with narrator Lemony Snicket (played by Patrick Warburton) warning that the new Netflix show is no delightful watch. Then the focus turns to Olaf and his mission to steal the children’s fortune, left to them by their parents after their untimely deaths: Read full article 
Netflix has unveiled a new Series of Unfortunate Events trailer, showing off Neil Patrick Harris’ excellent portrayal of the evil, wacky, will-stop-at-nothing-to-get-that-money Count Olaf. 
Neil Patrick Harris’ ability to convincingly become any person — whether male or female, young or old, ugly or beautiful — becomes abundantly clear in the latest ASOUE trailer. While some of us may’ve been a little skeptical of his casting initially, it’s hard to imagine anyone else in the role after seeing previews like this. 
The trailer begins with narrator Lemony Snicket (played by Patrick Warburton) warning that the new Netflix show is no delightful watch. Then the focus turns to Olaf and his mission to steal the children’s fortune, left to them by their parents after their untimely deaths: 
The Unfortunate Events trailer also presents new looks at colorful characters including Uncle Monty (Aasif Mandvi, below), Aunt Josephine (Alfre Woodard, below), and Justice Strauss (Joan Cusack). 
A Series of Unfortunate Events premieres all eight episodes of its first season on January 13, 2017. 
“Based on the internationally best-selling series of books by Lemony Snicket (aka Daniel Handler) and starring Emmy and Tony Award winner Neil Patrick Harris, A Series of Unfortunate Events recounts the tragic tale of the Baudelaire orphans — Violet, Klaus, and Sunny – whose evil guardian Count Olaf will stop at nothing to get his hands on their inheritance. The siblings must outsmart Olaf at every turn, foiling his many devious plans and disguises, in order to discover clues to their parents’ mysterious death.” 
Another trailer was released two weeks ago — you can watch it here . Is ‘Unfortunate Events’ looking as good as you hoped? 
Harris previously confirmed that each book will be adapted into two episodes of the show. The first season of ASOUE covers the first four books, so presumably season 2 will roughly cover another four books. There are a total of 13 books in Lemony Snicket’s series.

thread.section_title: Yahoo News - Latest News & Headlines
thread.title: U.S. Supreme Court backs Samsung in smartphone fight with Apple
thread.title_full: U.S. Supreme Court backs Samsung in smartphone fight with Apple

posts.author: Andrew Chung
posts.title: U.S. Supreme Court backs Samsung in smartphone fight with Apple
posts.text:
By Andrew Chung (Reuters) - The U.S. Supreme Court on Tuesday sided with Samsung in its big-money smartphone patent fight with Apple, throwing out an appeals court ruling that the South Korean company had to pay a $399 million penalty to its American rival for copying key iPhone designs.
The 8-0 ruling, written by Justice Sonia Sotomayor, held that a patent violator does not always have to fork over its entire profits from the sales of products using stolen designs, if the designs covered only certain components and not the whole thing.
The justices sent the case back to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington to determine how much Samsung must pay. But they did not provide a road map to juries and lower courts on how to navigate similar disputes in the future.
Apple spokesman Josh Rosenstock said in a statement that the U.S. company remained "optimistic that the lower courts will again send a powerful signal that stealing isn't right."
Samsung told Reuters in a statement the ruling was a "victory for Samsung and for all those who promote creativity, innovation and fair competition in the marketplace."
Following a 2012 jury verdict favoring Apple, Samsung initially was hit with nearly $930 million in penalties, later cut by $382 million, for infringing Apple's iPhone patents and mimicking its distinctive appearance in making the Galaxy and other competing devices.
Samsung in December 2015 paid its Cupertino, California-based rival $548 million. But Samsung took the matter to the Supreme Court, saying it should not have had to make $399 million of that payout for copying the patented designs of the iPhone's rounded-corner front face, bezel and colorful grid of icons that represent programs and applications.
With the products that used iPhone designs, Samsung went on to become the world's top smartphone maker.
Tuesday's ruling followed a ferocious legal battle between the world's top two smartphone manufacturers that began in 2011 when Apple sued Samsung for patent and trademark infringement. It was one of the most closely watched patent cases to come before the top U.S. court in recent years.
The legal dispute centered on whether the term "article of manufacture," on which design patent damages are calculated in U.S. patent law, should be interpreted as a finished product in its entirety, or merely a component in a complex product.
In court papers, Samsung, Apple and the U.S. government all agreed that the term could mean a component.
But Apple urged the Supreme Court to affirm the appeals court's ruling because Samsung presented no evidence that the article of manufacture in this case was anything less than its entire smartphone as sold. Samsung, meanwhile, said that it did not have to present such evidence.
Sotomayor, writing for the unanimous court, said that the law is clear. The term "article of manufacture is broad enough to encompass both a product sold to a consumer as well as a component of that product," she wrote.
PERIOD OF UNCERTAINTY
The justices nevertheless refused to devise a test for juries and lower courts to use to discern what a relevant article of manufacture is in a particular case, a task that could be fraught with difficulty when considering high-tech products.
"No doubt whether with Apple-Samsung, or some other design patent case, we are going to have a period of uncertainty where courts will be trying to formulate a test and what the boundaries are," Richard McKenna, an expert in design rights at the law firm Foley & Lardner in Milwaukee, said in an interview.
In court papers, Apple said its iPhone's success was tied to innovative designs, which other manufacturers quickly adopted in their own products. Samsung, in particular, made a deliberate decision to copy the iPhone's look and many user interface features, Apple said.
Samsung argued that it should not have had to turn over all its profits, saying that design elements contributed only marginally to a complex product with thousands of patented features.
Design patent fights very rarely reach the Supreme Court. It had not heard such a case in more than 120 years.
The case is Samsung Electronics Co, Ltd v. Apple Inc, in the Supreme Court of the United States, No. 15-777.
(Reporting by Andrew Chung in New York; additional reporting by Lawrence Hurley in Washington and Se Young Lee in Seoul; Editing by Will Dunham and Stephen Coates)

posts.title: Apple releases its third iOS 10 beta in the last six days; iOS 10 beta 7 is here
posts.text: News › Apple releases its third iOS 10 beta in the last six days; iOS 10 beta 7 is here Apple releases its third iOS 10 beta in the last six days; iOS 10 beta 7 is here Posted: Tags : iOS - iOS + Apple - Apple + Software updates - Software updates + Apple has released its third iOS 10 Beta in the last six days by rolling out iOS 10 Beta 7. The changelist for the seventh Beta of iOS 10 is basically the same as the changelist for the previous two versions of the update. One possibility as to why Apple has decided to gift us with numerous versions of the update might have to do with diagnostic tests that are being run to help Apple learn more about the battery issue that afflicts some units of the Apple iPhone 6s . The company announced the other day that before it sends out an update to fix the problem, it would release an update to help it gather more information about the issue.Certain iPhone 6s models produced during a specific period are going from 30% battery life to 0% as quickly as the snap of a finger. Plugging the phone in returns the battery life to 30%. Besides moving toward a software update to fix this problem, owners of iPhone 6s units with certain serial numbers are being given a free battery replacement by Apple.The iOS 10.2 update is expected to include the latest emoji from Unicode, additional effects for iMessage, and more. We could see iOS 10.2 launched as soon as next week. In the meantime, if you're a registered developer or have signed up with the public beta program, you can download and install iOS 10.2 beta 7 by going to Settings > General > Software Update .

posts.author: Shuli Ren
posts.title: Hon Hai: Biggest Winner From Apple’s “Strong” iPhone 8 Cycle, Says JP Morgan - Asia Stocks to Watch - Barrons.com
posts.text:
By Shuli Ren Apple ‘s (AAPL) assembler Hon Hai Precision Industry ( 2317.Taiwan ), or Foxconn, rose for the third day amid heavy buying after analysts grew bullish on Apple’s iPhone 8 product cycle. JP Morgan upgraded this stock to Buy with 100 new Taiwan dollars price target. 
JP Morgan thinks Apple will do a lot better with iPhone 8. Analyst Gokul Hariharan wrote:
After two years of lackluster demand, we foresee a strong iPhone 8 cycle, driven by: 1) a new form factor (5.85.8″) with OLED screen; 2) a move to glass casing for all iPhone models –the first new industrial design since iPhone 6; 3) likely price drop for the 4.7″ iPhone.
Apple will continue the trend of building larger phones. For instance, the 5’5″ iPhone Plus model is 40% of the total product mix in the iPhone 7 product cycle, up from 30% in the iPhone 6S product cycle. The bank thinks the 5’8″ OLED phone will be 45% of the iPhone 8 product cycle. “We believe the high-end 5.8″ OLED and lower-end 4.7″ models will do quite well and account for 90% of demand, while the middle-of-road 5.5″ LCD model could see very muted demand,” wrote the bank.
And this is good news for Foxconn because Foxconn has been losing its market share to Pegatron (4938.Taiwan) in the small 4’7″ models but its presence in the large-screen segment remains strong. (See chart)
Apple’s iPhone assembler Hon Hai has been losing market share in the small-screen segment but its presence in large-screen remains strong. JP Morgan As such, JP Morgan thinks Foxconn will see revenue recovery in 2017, growing by 12%, after 7% slump this year. On valuation, JP Morgan wrote:
Our Dec-17 PT of NT$100 is based on an FY18E P/E 11x, which is higher than Hon Hai’s mid-cycle P/E multiple. We believe Hon Hai should trade closer to the high end of the P/E range, given the better profit outlook and reviving growth momentum thanks to what we believe to be its favorable position in the strong iPhone 8 cycle.
The bank’s price target implies another 18% upside.

thread.section_title: Brafton
thread.title: Top Chrome extensions for content marketers
thread.title_full: Top Chrome extensions for content marketers

posts.author: Eric Wendt
posts.title: Top Chrome extensions for content marketers
posts.text:
Top Chrome extensions for content marketers December   
Apple’s “There’s an app for that” tag line became a buzzworthy slogan for the iPhone set years ago. It begs the question: Where’s Google’s catchphrase for Chrome extensions? 
Content marketing professionals who spend their days staring at glowing screens have a number of invaluable tools at their disposal thanks to Chrome extensions. No matter your objective, there’s likely an extension to help you achieve it. 
While Google doesn’t hold a monopoly on browser extensions, data shows Chrome is the preferred browser among the vast majority of internet users (73 percent), according to W3Schools. With that in mind, we’ll focus on the extensions provided by this browser that can help modern content marketers rock their careers. OneTab 
The genius behind OneTab is in its simplicity. Every content marketer eventually faces this conundrum: You’re crafting killer copy when suddenly your computer begins to shudder to a stop. What’s the problem? Well, it turns out having a million tabs open at once is taking its toll on your machine. 
Run the OneTab extension to sort all open tabs into a list. You can either restore tabs individually or all together. This way you save memory and precious processing speed without losing important reference materials. Save to Pocket 
Speaking of reference materials, finding excellent supporting sources is essential to creating authoritative content . However, arranging all this information can turn messy quic kly, especially if yo u need to save it for a later date. 
Save to Pocket makes saving everything simple. You can save articles, videos and more with one click, syncing the links to your preferred device to be viewed later at any time, internet connection or no. This also makes it easy to save non-work-related reads for breaks so you can stay focused on the task at hand. MozBar 
As a content marketer, you need to be aware of how each and every web page you create stacks up in terms of search engine optimization. At the same time, you need to be able to quickly determine the authority of websites you link out to. 
With MozBar, you can quickly scan SEO metrics for any web page, including your own. Examine on-page elements, preview schema markup and measure how difficult it will be to rank for a specific keyword all from a single Google Chrome extension. 
Similar Chrome Extensions: Page Analytics “You need to be able to quickly determine the authority of websites you link out to.” Buffer 
Successful content marketing and social media strategies go hand in hand. After all, excellent content needs to be shared and promoted to better capture clicks. Unfortunately, constantly publishing updates to Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn and other social platforms can be a laborious, time-consuming task. 
Buffer streamlines the process by allowing you to queue up social posts with a single click from any website. You can also count on detailed analytics regarding everything from likes and shares to retweets and mentions. 
Similar Chrome extensions: Hootsuite Pablo 
The team at Buffer understands content isn’t all about text, especially where social media is concerned. That’s why they created Pablo, which makes producing images specifically tailored for different social platforms a breeze. 
You can quickly and easily change image sizes, typography, fonts, colors and more. Simply open images or text in Pablo and get to editing. Check My Links 
Creating online content means working with links – lots of them. Incorporating authoritative links in your own content boosts your SEO and demonstrates trustworthiness to website visitors. However, broken links have the exact opposite effect. 
With Check My Links, you can ensure all links on a web page are functioning properly. If any are broken, you can quickly replace them and avoid getting dinged by Google or providing a less-than-stellar experience to site visitors. Boomerang 
More often than not, content marketing is a team effort, with much of the collaboration happening over email. While modern technology makes it easy for team members to work together from all around the world, pesky details like time differences can get in the way. 
Boomerang allows you to schedule email messages to be sent at specific times, making it easy to manage content marketing projects even when dealing with team members who may be hard at work while you’re fast asleep. Additionally, you can postpone receiving emails until certain times to ensure you don’t lose track of important communications that may get lost in an overflowing inbox. 
Similar Chrome extensions: Just Not Sorry , Right Inbox 
While extremely handy, the Google Chrome extensions mentioned above by no means constitute an exhaustive list. Every content marketer will have specific goals in mind, as well as distinct challenges to overcome. These are a great start to making you more productive, and it’s worth doing some digging to see what other tools Chrome offers to give your content marketing a boost. Eric Wendt is a writer and editor at Brafton. He discovered his love of words after realizing he was terrible at math. If he's not updating his Tumblr with poetry he's too embarrassed to share, there's a good chance he's out in search of the perfect pale ale. Thoughts?
